title: Permanent Bans are NOT Enough
body:
I'll keep it short and simple.

If a player was justifiably banned for something, it doesn't really mean a negative person is removed from the game. 

It means you've created a new smurf, and that new smurf is going to go do the same things he did to his elo to your new player (client) base. 

I made a 2nd acccount to practice, and almost EVERY SINGLE GAME I've filed a report AND gotten an immediate feedback report. I'm not exaggerating. Thats a ridiculous amount of players crapping all over games. It's good punishment is swift and all, but they usually are bragging about making a new account and not caring about the report. "Idgaf". "Accounts are free". "this my X number account" "X insult"

They run it down mid, say fuck you for not opening mid lane at 10 when they lose, call out their jg's position in all chat, or trolling _hard_. This shit's bad man. Imagine someone whose never played this game having to deal with that.  I love this game and I feel I might just let my smurf die to avoid those players.

No system is 100%, but I think its time to get a stricter one anyways.

replies.body:
Out of curiosity, what is your proposal?

* Email addresses are disposable, as are phone numbers. These are unreliable for ensuring players don't make new accounts.
* The game is a free-to-play game with a player age of 13+, so you can't tie it to credit cards.
* The game is multi-national, so you can't tie it to social media for any specific site. Further, many sites you COULD use do not let 13-year-olds make profiles.
* The game is played by many families, played at colleges, and played at cyber cafes, so you can't ban computers or locations.
* Personal ID bans take time to gather enough data to be 100% confident a player has returned on a new account, and that gives more than enough time for those players to ruin additional games.

In short, Riot can't really enforce anything stricter than a permanent ban, in my eyes. Would be interested to see if you have any suggestions.

You're not wrong, but more deterrents couldn't hurt, right? I doubt Riot's bottom line would be adversely affected if they made it a teensy bit more complicated to make a new account.

(I still think the best solution is to require an amount of money up front for every new account and then pay that cost back several times over in RP, like a new account costs $5 but then begins with $20 worth of RP, but I doubt Riot would be willing to implement that for several reasons).

> [{quoted}](name=Jo0o,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=UxG5apjF,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2018-03-15T17:20:32.377+0000)You're not wrong, but more deterrents couldn't hurt, right? I doubt Riot's bottom line would be adversely affected if they made it a teensy bit more complicated to make a new account.

Every time you make it more complicated to make a new account you make it less inviting to players who want to try *League*, while those insistent on returning post-ban are likely to jump through the hoops anyway.

> (I still think the best solution is to require an amount of money up front for every new account and then pay that cost back several times over in RP, like a new account costs $5 but then begins with $20 worth of RP, but I doubt Riot would be willing to implement that for several reasons).

This definitely has a number of issues, including the previously stated "requiring payment," which not all players can afford or acquire methods of payment for. Additionally, given that account sellers exist, money clearly isn't a deciding factor in players choosing to return.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=UxG5apjF,comment-id=000300000000,timestamp=2018-03-15T17:26:45.670+0000)
>
> Every time you make it more complicated to make a new account you make it less inviting to players who want to try *League*, while those insistent on returning post-ban are likely to jump through the hoops anyway.

I'm not sure if I follow your reasoning. Permanent bans in themselves are deterrents to a player returning to the game, and I'm sure I read somewhere that a large percentage of permanently banned players stay away, opting not to bother with a new account. 

Tying one's League account to something tied to an individual's identity, such as a personal email or a facebook profile, shouldn't be a real deterrent for new players. It would, however, be an extra hoop to jump through for a banned player attempting to jump back into the game. 

How many players would Riot lose if they enforced one account per email, and banned emails along with the accounts that were associated with them? That doesn't seem like it would prevent new players from joining the game at all. 

> This definitely has a number of issues, including the previously stated "requiring payment," which not all players can afford or acquire methods of payment for. Additionally, given that account sellers exist, money clearly isn't a deciding factor in players choosing to return.

Well, if Riot actually implemented this, it would destroy account selling entirely. Riot currently plays wack-a-mole with botted accounts, and account sellers are counting on some percentage of those accounts making it past Riot's defenses to level 30, right? If every attempt they make costs them money, their entire business model would be thrown out the window. At the very least, the price of each account would need to be increased significantly.

> [{quoted}](name=Jo0o,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=UxG5apjF,comment-id=0003000000000000,timestamp=2018-03-15T17:36:13.715+0000)How many players would Riot lose if they enforced one account per email, and banned emails along with the accounts that were associated with them? That doesn't seem like it would prevent new players from joining the game at all. 

It does make legitimate smurfing more frustrating though, and additionally doesn't really prevent the issue at hand, because emails are disposable. The issue here is that a lot of banned players *don't* come back, and those that do are usually quiet persistent.

> Well, if Riot actually implemented this, it would destroy account selling entirely. Riot currently plays wack-a-mole with botted accounts, and account sellers are counting on some percentage of those accounts making it past Riot's defenses to level 30, right? If every attempt they make costs them money, their entire business model would be thrown out the window. At the very least, the price of each account would need to be increased significantly.

That's fair, but it would also mean League has a cost to test out, and that banned players willing to pay that cost can get their stuff back faster. I just don't see it as a net upside, loss to revenue from giving out free money aside.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=UxG5apjF,comment-id=00030000000000000000,timestamp=2018-03-15T17:40:19.291+0000)
>
> It does make legitimate smurfing more frustrating though, and additionally doesn't really prevent the issue at hand, because emails are disposable. The issue here is that a lot of banned players *don't* come back, and those that do are usually quiet persistent.

Emails are disposable, but making a new one for every new account is a deterrent, right? Blocking their original personal email along with the banned account means they need to maintain that disposable email if they want to purchase RP and such, or if they ever have a security issue. 

> That's fair, but it would also mean League has a cost to test out, and that banned players willing to pay that cost can get their stuff back faster. I just don't see it as a net upside, loss to revenue from giving out free money aside.

Make the cost trigger at level 10/15/20, then. 

The revenue upside would be similar to a major reason why Riot bans people even when they've spent hundreds or thousands of dollars on the game: removing toxic players from the community keeps the community happy and more willing to buy RP shit overall.

> [{quoted}](name=Jo0o,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=UxG5apjF,comment-id=000300000000000000000000,timestamp=2018-03-15T17:53:13.856+0000)Make the cost trigger at level 10/15/20, then.

Again, I feel Riot is pretty keen on ensuring that players do not NEED to spend money to play League. I can't see that changing, nor do I think changing it is a good idea. Further, putting a cost on higher levels wouldn't stop people making multiple accounts and poisoning the low-level experience.

Making it harder would only make it worse for those who did nothing wrong, while the ones who were banned are going to go through any hoop regardless. Yes you're making it harder for them, but they're going to do it anyway

I've proposed this as well, the problem with it is that it would unfairly impact people who play on a shared device such as a library computer, a shared home computer, or a computer at an internet cafe.

Now I don't think that this is necessarily a bad thing, perhaps Riot could institute a process by which owners of such shared devices could appeal to have the device un-blocked after showing that the individual responsible has faced real-world consequences of some kind, such as being banned from the cafe or library, or punished by their head of household if on a shared home computer.

> [{quoted}](name=Pacattack25,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=UxG5apjF,comment-id=00030002,timestamp=2018-03-15T21:52:03.565+0000)If he doesn't have one then I do: MODERATORS PLAYING THE GAMES - your most honored players could effectively apply for a staff postion to play low level games to try to keep the toxicity in low level low - if a moderator goes out of hand you know who has moderator position and what they are doing, but basically you have people who want to keep the game clear playing the game who have the capability to hand out punishments INSTANTLy for games that get out of hand.

I can fairly confidently say that if Riot were to even CONSIDER giving that level of in-game power to players (which I'm pretty sure they wouldn't do, as the potential for abuse is super high), they'd want to make sure each and every one is specifically briefed on exactly what constitutes problematic behavior -- which means a large amount of time expenditure. Even then you'd need thousands -- likely TENS of thousands -- of individuals doing this, and one rogue player could cause a LOT of damage before being identified as giving incorrect punishments. Since you wouldn't necessarily have to do away with the auto system, you could instead use them to scout troll actions. They could volunteer, but then be vetted like accounts are for PBE. Maybe start with players from the PBE pool.

I don't like this idea. The biggest reason is that they've tried it in extensive experiments in the past, and they have big data on it. It didn't work, and a large enough percentage of players resorted to other, harder-to-identify forms of toxicity that it was discontinued.

Additionally, I don't see a problem with a team-based game removing those community members who have proven themselves so problematic that they have been denied their ability to communjcate with their team.

In short, I'm against most systems that go easier on toxic players unless there is a corresponding ADVANTAGE to the rest of the community. Having a bunch of players who are know to get angry at their team AND literally can't communicate doesn't seem like an improvement.

> [{quoted}](name=The Djinn,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=UxG5apjF,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2018-03-15T17:05:57.621+0000)
>
> Out of curiosity, what is your proposal?

Want a simple solution?

Rito's epic punishment system is linear regardless of offense category. There are basically no merits to this flow, and it is extremely ineffective at accomplishing what it sets out to do:
10-game chat restrict -> 25-game chat restrict -> 14-day ban -> perma-ban

So what you end up with are permabanned accounts for "toxic" chat. (Which seems to be judged on an "if you wouldn't say it to a 2 year old" judgment system.) What do those players do? Leave, maybe. Or get a new account, with a fresh honor level, no chat restriction or whatever. So what do they do? Reform, maybe. Or not.

I propose my radical, life-changing, fantastical solution: **TWO(?!)** punishment tracks:

- Toxic in chat?  10-Game Chat Restrict -> 25-Game Chat Restrict -> Permanent Chat Restrict -> Permanent CHAT Ban
 - *Extremely* toxic in chat? (Racism, etc.) Start at Permanent Chat Restrict or Permanent Chat Ban
- Intentionally feeding? 14-Day ban -> Permanent ban

Notice that the chat-related punishments bar you from using---you guessed it---chat! If Tyler2 is extremely toxic in chat and gets permanently _chat banned_, he's going to have a lot less incentive to level (or buy, etc.)  a new account. Now he can continue playing but cannot flame his teammates. If he redirects his efforts by intentionally feeding, now his account gets banned.

This still has the potential eventuality that accounts get banned and players acquire new accounts, but in the likely much more common case people will continue to play but just without chat privileges. Now:

- They keep their skins, rank, etc
 - Fewer smurfs! When that Platinum or Diamond(+) player gets chat banned, they continue playing in their elo instead of starting fresh at high Silver/low Gold.
 - Fewer [anti-smurfs?]! When that Bronze player gets chat banned, they continue playing in Bronze instead of starting fresh at high Silver/low Gold.
 - Fewer [anti-]smurfs means less toxicity. The Diamond Riven player stomping the Silver Yasuo in top lane is probably going to cause the Silver player to get flamed. Likewise, the Bronze player that starts over at basically Gold 5 MMR is probably going to feed and CS poorly until they fall back to Bronze, because they are playing above their elo.
- Fewer accounts are created 
 - More summoner names for everyone!
- Less people are raging in chat
 - More people retaining accounts without chat privileges vs acquiring new accounts
- The message regarding intentionally feeding is firmer and stronger

I literally cannot conceive a single reason as to why anyone would think this is not simply a better solution.

I think this would help greatly.

To add to your point

I think moderators could help, even contributing to this system (to determine the track). Give them very high vetting standards with a chest as incentive to view a game or two.

Then at least a captcha for login (if it works at all against bots in this game. Idk if it would for sure, just because its simple and I've never seen it used for League)

I think moderators would help greatly as well. I recently played a game with a Riot player on my team and I swear that was the least toxic game I have ever played in, ever. People were apologizing for other peoples' mistakes.

A moderator system doesn't have to be complicated. For example:

- 1000 matchmade games _at Honor Level 5_. ( Maybe this becomes Honor Level 6?)
 - Dropping below Honor Level 5 at any point revokes moderator status
- Moderators can flag accounts, triggering human-review, and leave a note as is done in regular reports.
 - The moderator doesn't have the power to ban
 - Trivial flagging could revoke moderator privileges and/or reduce honor level

Boom, simple. Give them some loading screen flair and your game pretty much just became toxicity-free. It's exactly like highway patrol and speed trap cops: You give tickets when you need to, but your presence serves as a deterrence in most cases. Who's going to flame, intentionally feed, or ragequit knowing that there's someone in the game that can trigger a guaranteed review on your behavior?

Then for the games where no moderator is present, the standard report system continues on its merry way.

Email and phone addresses are disposable, but considering how much of an investment a new phone is, it would certainly be a lot more disincentivizing to require both from a player. Repeat offenders would have to pay upwards of $100 out of pocket each time they get banned, just to make a new account.

If Riot wanted to enforce this, they could release a phone app that links with your account. On top of providing 2-Factor Authentication (which will only improve security against scams and account theft), it would also be able to ensure that a problem player couldn't spoof the system simply by changing their phonenumber.

Tbh I think that would deter all but the most dedicated shit-stirrers.

Create a "priority pool" for players with certain "mile-stones" on their account , like hours played ,how much MONEY they have invested into their account, date account was created etc. with this you can create an algorithm and filter out players into these "priority" pools accordingly,  as these players are less likely to grief because they will be at risk of losing their access to the "priority pool",by having their accounts banned.

You basically trying to evaluate or define and account by giving it a rating .With a rating you will likely be able to determine whether or not the person on the account is serious and holds his account dear to him OR if he doesn't and considers it expendable.

Because its a 13+ game that's free you can't regulate it in a simple cookie cutter type of way. There is no blanket solution to this ,you need various solutions in conjunction with one another to actually to make things work.

This will help low elo ranked games ,where anyone can buy a level 30 account for 10$ and troll/grief till they get banned over and over ...

Well, keep in mind that your new account was likely within 2-3 games recognized to be much higher skill than an average new player, and as such you were by definition matched with players who were smurfs. New players do not tend to get matched with smurfs unless they constantly duo with friends.

I can attest to League being ridiculously toxic and confusing for new players. I would even go as far as saying that the elo system when leveling is broken beyond all recognition. 

I am a DotA 2 player with approx. 3.5k hours in game. A friend suggested I try league of legends as well. One weekend I was bored enough to try and I created an account. 


The first games were easy of course (bot matches) and then the first 5 matches against real players were easily won with my moba knowledge from DotA (ganking, csing, objectives and basic spacing and prediction). HOWEVER, after about 10 games of decently challenging opponents where I really felt I was learning about LoL and aclimitmising to the structure of a different MOBA beast, things went horribly wrong. Suddenly my level 6/8 account was matched against level 20 and above accounts. I even had some opponents that were level 30 and were mid silver tier players. 

This turned my games sour in the worst way. I was flamed constantly for not knowing every skill of every hero in the game. I was reported constantly and I lost 10ish straight games. That's when I quit. DotA was no where near that level of absolute ridiculousness. When I started in 2012 I played with my friends and I fed horribly, but I was having fun and learning at the same time. 

I really think measures need to be taken to ensure new players have a decent experience first time. The level 30 grind is far too long as is, compared to almost every other Moba. 


In conclusion, what I have seen of the matchmaking system in league has led me to view it as archaic, with no place in the modern Moba world.

I don't hate the game, I hate the system (as well as some of the players).

They really wouldn't.  Let me give you an extended list as to why IP bans can't and won't work:

- Dynamic IPs change (not just from power cycling a router) at random intervals dependent upon the ISP.  They can also be changed by use of ipconfig /release all, ipconfig /renew all and other means also.  
- Many people that play League do so from a college campus, banning an IP could block an entire campus or at least a block of computers on a campus.  Thus, innocent people would be banned.  
- Families share internet connections.  An IP ban may block an entire family because of the actions of one individual.  

Also, as is the case with any system, those that want to come back will do so because ANY measure you use has a workaround, IP addresses are easiest to change, MAC Addresses/hardware IDs are pretty easy to spoof, there are websites dedicated to circumventing two-factor authentication issues so that you don't have to use your real phone number and so on.  

Threads like this, while certainly based upon good intentions, aren't really realistic in their solutions.  Permabans in a free-to-play game are relatively meaningless, the only way Riot could really mitigate this issue is by changing the fundamental structure of their business model to a subscription based service, even then it would only have a marginal impact on toxicity and would have a far worse consequence to the number of players that they would lose as a result.
